Entropy is not disorder
well I'm 19 but we range from 19 - 24 here
Word! I'm so tired of hearing entropy equals disorder...

Entropy is not disorder.  It's the measure (like area or volume, only generalized to a gazillion dimensions: one for every component of the location and velocity of every particle in the system) of the set of fully-described states of the system (micro-states) that correspond to that observable characteristic (macro-state) of the system.  Or the integral of heat flow divided by temperature, integrated over any path from some reference state to the state in question.  (Or something like that.  This lecture should have provided a review of that, not just the kindergarten non-explanation.)

@AsakuraAvan Mainly because it is easier to explain the geometry of the molecule if you sp3 hybridise the system. However, you do not need to employ hybridisation and you can treat ammonia with molecular orbital theory. The benefit of MO theory is that it explains why the 3 stretching vibrations exhibit 2 vibrational bands.

+Dan Wylie-Sears sure why not

It's pretty common in chemistry to gloss over certain things that are covered in more detail in physics.  Especially anything related to thermodynamics, I've noticed (for example, a physics textbook might stress that the first law of thermodynamics applies to isolated systems, I've yet to see any general chemistry material even talk about closed vs isolated systems in relation to thermodynamics).    I've seen several instructors do this, and say things like "physicists get all nit-picky about this topic, but chemists only need to use this part of this topic..."   It makes sense to do this to save time because most STEM majors have to have a minimum one year of general physics anyway, and entropy will naturally be given more attention in physics.
Heather Leisure  The book they’re using makes these distinctions, so they’re there if the students want to look. If they’re chemistry majors, they’ll get the full picture in Pchem 1 later
